variant.question: It is a clear night and there is a moderate, warm wind blowing across a steep valley. One probable result is that...

options.text: an inversion forms as still air in the valley cools.
unstable air forms as the warm air comes over the valley.
thunderstorms develop over the valley.
orographic fog forms on the upwind side of the valley.

variant.question: A mountain breeze (katabatic wind) blows

options.text: down the slope during the night
up the slope during the night.
up the slope during the day.
down the slope during the day.

variant.question: The sea breeze is a wind...

options.text: occurring only in the lower layers of the atmosphere in daytime.
that reaches up to the tropopause in daytime.
blowing at night in mid-latitudes.
occurring only in mid-latitudes and in daytime.

variant.question: An 'ANABATIC' wind is a wind which

options.text: blows up a hill or mountain mainly during the day.
blows down a hill or mountain mainly during the day.
blows down a hill or mountain mainly during the night.
blows up a hill or mountain mainly during the night.

variant.question: In a land- and sea-breeze circulation the land breeze blows...

options.text: during the night and is weaker than the sea breeze.
during the night and is stronger than the sea breeze.
during the day and is weaker than the sea breeze.
during the day and is stronger than the sea breeze.

variant.question: Mountain waves have been observed over the Pyrenees Mountains, therefore, at the lee side, the layer of the air mass at the ridge line is (1) _____. In the air mass above the mountains wind speed will (2) _____ with height and the wind direction will (3) _____ with height.

options.text: (1) stable; (2) increase; (3) remains relatively constant.
(1) stable; (2) decrease; (3) veer by at least 90º.
(1) unstable; (2) increases; (3) remain relatively constant.
(1) stable; (2) increase; (3) back by at least 90º.

variant.question: A 'sea breeze' blows

options.text: from sea during the day.
from sea during the night.
from land during the day.
from land during the night.

variant.question: A katabatic wind mostly blows

options.text: down the slope during the night.
down the slope during the day.
up the slope during the day.
up the slope during the night.

variant.question: Low level jet streams at relatively low altitudes may form:

options.text: At night just above the inversion created by the cooling of the air closest to the surface in the atmosphere.
In the middle of the eye of a TRS.
Inside large Cb clouds during the dissipating stage.
In very unstable atmospheres during the day when convection is strongest.

variant.question: Low level jet streams at relatively low altitudes may form:

options.text: At night just above the inversion created by the cooling of the air closest to the surface in the atmosphere
In the middle of the eye of a Tropical Revolving Storm (TRS)
In very unstable atmospheres during the day when convection is strongest
Inside large Cb clouds during the dissipating stage

variant.question: Low level jet streams at relatively low altitudes may form:

options.text: At night just above the inversion created by the cooling of the air closest to the surface in the atmosphere
In the middle of the eye of a TRS
Inside large Cb clouds during the dissipating stage
In very unstable atmospheres during the day when convection is strongest

variant.question: What is correct regarding the dissipation of the nocturnal jet?

options.text: It dissipates in the morning as the air warms and vertical mixing sets in.
It dissipates within the following hour as the ground is cooling by radiation.
It dissipates hardly as it needs frontal systems to get involved in the process, which takes up to several days.
The nocturnal jets have a precise location where can almost always find them.

variant.question: A Katabatic wind is a flow of...

options.text: cold air down the slope of a mountain.
warm air blowing from land to sea in summer.
warm air up the slope of a hill, caused by surface heating.
cold air blowing from sea to land.

variant.question: On a clear night, a katabatic wind blows down a mountain range. The temperature 1 000 ft above the ground is 2 °C. What temperature can be expected at the surface?
What is the circulation pattern of the anabatic wind?

options.text: From the valley to the top of the mountain due to warming of air in the valley.
From the valley water source up to the first mountain vegetation.
From the top of the mountain down to the valley due to cold air from the top.
From the valley to the top of the mountain due to instability and adiabatic warming of air in a valley.

variant.question: The most frequent wind direction in a valley near the ground caused by thermal effects is...

options.text: up the valley during daylight hours.
up the valley at night.
down the valley during daylight as much as at night.
down the valley during daylight hours.

variant.question: Which of the following is true of a 'land breeze'?

options.text: It blows from land to water.
It blows from water to land.
It blows by day.
It blows only at noon.

variant.question: When surface winds are moderate or strong, conditions that can be expected in mountain areas are...

options.text: Updrafts and downdrafts, turbulence, and wind shear with changes of wind speed and wind direction.
Relatively smooth conditions close to the ground, unless a mountain wave exists, or the mountains are steep-sided and irregular.
Mountain waves, resulting in downdrafts in excess of the climb performance of most turbojet-engined aeroplanes.
Severe turbulence at all altitudes up to the tropopause.

variant.question: Sea breezes are most likely to occur when a...

options.text: slack pressure gradient and clear skies result in relatively high land temperatures.
strong pressure gradient, relatively high sea temperatures, and overcast conditions persist.
strong pressure gradient, relatively high sea temperatures, and clear skies at night exist.
slack pressure gradient, relatively high sea temperatures and overcast conditions persist.

variant.question: In which of the following circumstances would the formation of a low-level jet stream in the evening be most likely?

options.text: An inflow of cold air over land or strong radiation cooling in the evening can lead to an inversion; at or just below the top of the inversion a low-level jet stream can form.
When warm air in the evening moves into the friction layer near the surface, a low-level jet stream can sometimes form, within or above the top of the layer.
The inflow of air into the base of a CB or TS at night can result, occasionally, in the concentration of the wind near the cold surface, which leads to the formation of a low-level jet stream.
When the airflow near the surface is forced against a mass of cold air ahead of a warm front at night, the low-level wind increases and can occasionally form a low-level jet stream.

variant.question: What is a 'land breeze'?

options.text: Air moving from land over water at night.
Air moving from sea over land by night.
Air moving from land over sea by day.
Air moving from sea over land by day.

variant.question: A 'KATABATIC' wind is a wind which

options.text: blows down a hill or mountain mainly during the night.
blows up a hill or mountain mainly during the day.
blows down a hill or mountain mainly during the day.
blows up a hill or mountain mainly during the night.

variant.question: The typical height of the vertical area affected by sea breeze in mid-latitudes is approximately

options.text: 100 ft

variant.question: Which statement about the wind on the leeward side of mountains is true?

options.text: The turbulence might be hazardous, especially for small aircraft because of excessive roll and pitch changes.
You should hold firmly on the steering wheel, but the wind will last only a couple of seconds.
The lee ward side is less dangerous than the opposite (windward) side of the mountains.
Fly as low as possible to avoid the up- and downdrafts.

variant.question: A mountain range runs north-south. It is located to the west of your destination. Wind 270°/30 kt, air is unstable and rain is falling on the windward side from a cloud with a base at 2 000 ft. What can you expect at your destination?

options.text: Dry and warm wind with a cloud base above 2 000 ft.
Wet and cold wind with no clouds.
Dry and warm wind with a cloud base below 2 000 ft.
Wet and cold wind with heavy precipitation and hail.

variant.question: What is correct regarding an anabatic wind? It can be described as a wind that blows:

options.text: Upslope due to warming of air in a valley.
Downslope due to cold air that slides down a valley.
Downslope due to the radiation of heat from the Earth’s surface.
Upslope caused by instability due the adiabatic heating in a valley.

variant.question: When in summer calm and clear conditions exist, a station on the shore of a large body of water will experience wind

options.text: from the water in daytime and from the land at night.
from the land in daytime and from the water at night.
continually from land to water.
continually from water to the land.

variant.question: When in summer calm and clear conditions exist, a station on the shore of a large body of water will experience wind...

options.text: from the water in daytime and from the land at night.
from the land in daytime and from the water at night.
continually from water to the land.
continually from land to water.

variant.question: You are flying a heading of 270° to an airport at 1 500 ft elevation. There is a mountain ridge to the west of the airport, running north-south, and the wind is from the west and the conditions are unstable. What kind of wind can you expect during the approach?

options.text: A Foehn wind.
Heavy precipitation.
Lee waves.
A rotor zone wind.

variant.question: A mountain range spans from South to North and the wind is 270°/10 kt. Orographic fog is expected:

options.text: On the windward side of the mountain.
On the southern part of the mountain.
In the evening.
On the leeward side of the mountain.

variant.question: A mountain range spans from South to North and the wind is 270°/10 kt. Where is orographic fog expected?

options.text: On the windward side of the mountain.
In the evening.
On the southern part of the mountain.
On the leeward side of the mountain.

variant.question: A mountain range spans from South to North and the wind is from the west. Where is the orographic low expected?

options.text: On the leeward side of the mountain.
Only in the Alps.
On the windward side of the mountain.
On the northern part of the mountain.

variant.question:
Check the correctness of the following statements.1. A blocking high must be a warm high 
 2. Sea-breeze fronts only occur at mid-latitudes

options.text: 1 and 2 are not correct
1 is not correct, 2 is correct
1 is correct, 2 is not correct
1 and 2 are correct

variant.question: What is the name of the hot, local wind, that blows downwards from mountain chains? In the Alps, for instance, it may exist both as a southerly or northerly wind depending on the weather situation.

options.text: Foehn.
Mistral.
Scirocco.
Bora.

options.text: Foehn
Scirocco
Mistral
Bora

options.text: Foehn wind.

Ghibli.

options.text: Bora

options.text: Bora

variant.question: A mountain range runs north-south and reaches 4 000 feet AMSL. It is located to the west of your destination, which is at 1 000 feet AMSL. options.text: A Foehn wind.
Advection fog.
A lee wave.
Rotor streaming turbulence.

variant.question: What is a typical phenomenon created by valleys and mountain slopes?

options.text: Valley inversion
Valley winds
Mountain obstruction
Advection fog

variant.question: After a sunny day, followed by a long clear night, you take-off from an airfield at mid-latitudes an hour before sunrise. The field is not situated close to the coast. Though the pressure gradient is rather large, the easterly surface wind is weak and makes:

options.text: a sudden strong increase in wind speed and strong veering of the wind a short time after take-off.
a squally wind up to great heights.
little increase in wind speed and little veering of the wind up to an height of 5 000 ft.
large but gradual increase in wind speed and large but gradual veering of the wind up to a height of 5 000 ft.

variant.question: After a sunny day, followed by a long clear night, you take-off from an airfield at mid-latitudes an hour before sunrise. The field is not situated close to the coast. Though the pressure gradient is rather large, the easterly surface wind is weak and makes

options.text: a sudden strong increase in wind speed and strong veering of the wind a short time after take-off.
a squally wind up to great heights.
little increase in wind speed and little veering of the wind up to an height of 5 000 ft.
large but gradual increase in wind speed and large but gradual veering of the wind up to a height of 5 000 ft.

variant.question: A typical phenomenon created by valleys and mountain slopes is called:

options.text: Valley inversion.
Advection fog.
Valley winds.
Mountain obstruction.

variant.question: Two aircraft are flying simultaneously in level flight at different flight levels on opposite tracks overhead a given position. Aircraft A flying at FL 070 experiences a 30 kts headwind. Aircraft B flying at FL 060 experiences a 20 kts headwind. None of the aircraft experiences cross wind. This wind condition will be referred to as:

options.text: vertical wind shear only.
no wind shear since the absolute value of the difference in wind velocity per height unit is too small to fit the definition of wind shear at all.
vertical and horizontal wind shear.
horizontal wind shear only.

variant.question: What is likely to happen in a valley?

options.text: Valley Inversion.
Mountain obstruction.
Advection fog.
Valley winds.

options.text: katabatic wind.
valley wind.
foehn breeze.
anabatic wind.

variant.question: In a mountain-valley wind circulation, the mountain wind blows

options.text: at night down from the mountains.
during the day up from the valley.
